bibl.title: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Mrs. Mason Young, December 23, 1900

div1.p: Kean writes about studying for his upcoming promotion examination. He notes that the scientists are seeing important results from the mosquito experiments. A dinner will be held in honor of Finlay.

div1.head: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Mrs. Mason Young, December 23, 1900
div1.opener:
A kiss from
Martha
and one from
Bobs
Columbia Bks
December 23rd
HEADQUARTERS DEPARTMENT
OF HAVANA AND PINAR DEL RIO,
QUEMADOS, CUBA
My dearest Gran
div1.p:
I feel that I have
by no means kept up
my record as a Dutiful
Son since Louise and the
kids arrived. I have
been especially busy lately
because I have have to
go into Havana for my
work, and too, since the
Army bill loomed above
the horizon I spend all
my spare half hours study-
ing the hundred and one
new departures of modern
medical science in pre-
paration for my examina
tion. For the bill will
give me my promotion &
I expect my examination
within a month.

I suppose Louise has written
you the brilliant results of
the recent mosquito exper-
iments, which have proved
the theory beyond the per-
adventure of a doubt.

I won't begin on this sub-
ject as I never know
when to stop. I will only
mention that the effort
to make men catch the
disease from infected
bedding & clothing has
failed entirely altho.
the house was kept heated & moist and
some of the clothing was foul to a
degree that was dreadful to see & to
smell. So quarantine of goods and
disinfection for yellow fever are now
things of the past, and our friends of
the Marine hospital service will have
not little to do. There was a big din-
ner last night in honor of Dr Carlos
Finlay who has been maintaining the
mosquito theory for the past 15 years
though he was never able to prove it.
All the prominent physicians of the town were
there & Gen. Wood & the Medical officer of
higher rank. Your humble servant sat
on Dr Finlays right, & enjoyed himself
greatly. This dinner marks the profes-
sional and official acceptance of
the theory in Havana, and I drew
a mosquito order which Gen Wood
will publish tomorrow, ordering the
use of mosquito bars, and the distruct-
ion of mosquito larvae by kerosineoil.
Well Louise & Mrs Stark got their box
on the 25th and were
greatly pleased with
its contents. They are
both as busy as can
be with Xmas prepar-
ations. The mess is
so far very congenial &
jolly, and altho- it keeps
Louise pretty busy to
run it, she can do it
so much more reasonably
and so much better
than any one else how-
ever that she has be-
come reconciled to the
idea. Mrs Burton &
the two Burton girls
come tomorrow. If they
are as pleasant mess-
mates as the Col. all
will be well.

What I will do after
Col. Havard returns is
still undecided, as I
hate to cause the Starks
a move. I am going
to ask Havard to leave
me unassigned until
after my examination
so that I can get a
little chance to study.

For I havent had any
to speak of since I
left Fort Warren & for
over a year did not
have any books.
As soon as I get my majority I will
be perfectly willing to come back
to the U. S. and think it probable
that I will do so in the spring.
Mama has improved so much since her
arrival, and seems to enjoy Louise and
the children so much. She is I think
much happier than she has been since
my father's death. You ought to see her
pet and admire the beautiful Bobs,
who improves in good looks and size
daily. Martha has lost most of her
beauty with her hair, but is as ruddy
and fat as can be - and reasonably
good. She has some playmates now, the
Stark boys & Caldwell's & others.

Louise says she will write you a long letter
as soon as Xmas is over and tell you all
about it. Mama was very sorry not to see you
but Mr Young seems to have given her a
fine time and quite won her heart.
I hope he received a box of Portages cigars
which I sent him. We sent Dr McCarroll a
silver dish and Manie a Jap- workbox which is
the extent of the Kean Xmas.
With love to all the family, I am dearly Gran
